body: Really great stuff!
Hi @Vic020 any more updates?
@bolkedebruin can u plz rebase and squash your commits, incase this PR is still relevant.
Sorry for the delay, had a presentation to prepare. Makes sense, makes me think if it doesn't apply to a few other API calls.

I have a new concern: for the DataFlow operator I need to fix something so I could propagate the credentials defined in the connection to the DataFlow process. With a key on disk it's easy, just set the **GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS**, point it to the key. What would I do with the JSON key? Write it do disk on a temp location and set the env variable every time the DataFlow process is set?

see: https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/application-default-credentials
@jlowin could you rebase and maybe add the potential breaking change to UPDATING.md.
Are we waiting for some fix in this PR, or is it ready to get in?
I've just noticed AIRFLOW-160 replaced refresh_dags_every with min_file_process_interval and it's configurable via airflow.cfg. So I'll close the original issue on JIRA. Thanks!

@gwax Thank you for this contribution. It works well and I will use it in production in few days!
However, I notice some limitations in my basic usage and I would like to have your hints about it:

• If my `schedule_interval is None` it raises an exception because it can not compare `NoneType` with `datetime`. (It comes that I unschedule my DAG in order to manually trigger it :/)

• My second point is about manual trigger with a defined `schedule_interval`. It obviously does not work because it's not the "last". Logs : `- Checking latest only with left_window: 2016-10-24 23:00:00 right_window: 2016-10-25 00:00:00 now: 2016-10-24 22:45:41.283157` :) 

So, this operator make impossible to manually trigger a DAG. Do you have any workaround ?
lgtm
lgtm.. though we dont use oracle so can't comment on the impact of the change..
+1 for idea.. we also use datadog..
I rebased the PR and added a JIRA Issue, however it seems that the tests fail at random due to database problems.
+1 we're evaluating dog, I'll have a talk with our service manager if he likes to try it.
We're experiencing extremely slow backfills. I'll see if can test this PR in our staging environment (on Friday).

+1 @znichols Welcome to the community!

@yuanfeiz 
Background job coordinator and executor is definitely Airflow's use case. That said, we usually expect the heavy lifting to be done by the various systems Airflow talks to, not usually the airflow workers.

What this means is that usually, Airflow tasks are either : 
1) A sensor, which checks for a particular condition and returns True or False.
2) An operator which does delegates some work to a system (Say for instance a database, Spark or such)
3) A transfer operator, where we move data from one system to another, sometimes by using the local filesystem as an intermediate.

Airflow does not usually have tasks output data in the Python sense, mostly because there is no easy way in a distributed system to guarantee that the next task will be executed on the same worker, so loading the output of a task in memory is not usually useful.

For small amounts of data there the [XCom system](https://airflow.incubator.apache.org/concepts.html#xcoms) , which aims at being a lightweight cross communication system between tasks.

Maybe you could describe your use case a little better in a JIRA task [here](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW) or on the dev mailing list dev@airflow.incubator.apache.org, and we could see where to take this.

Let me know if you have any more questions.

Also, please prefix your commit and PR subject lines with `[AIRFLOW-XXX]` in the future (e.g. `[AIRFLOW-600]`).

I will fix it on merge this time.
@btallman What is the need for this PR? What is broken?

This existing code is suspicious.. I don't believe the `dag_run.start_date` will ever equal the`ti.start_date`.

I see this function is currently called in 2 places : 
Once in jobs.py's `_execute_task_instances` function:

```
                # todo: remove this logic when backfills will be part of the scheduler
                dag_run = task_instance.get_dagrun()
                if dag_run and dag_run.is_backfill:
                    continue
```

and once in ./ti_deps/deps/dagrun_exists_dep.py's `_get_dep_statuses` function:

```
        dag = ti.task.dag
        dagrun = ti.get_dagrun(session)
        if not dagrun:
            # The import is needed here to avoid a circular dependency
            from airflow.models import DagRun
            running_dagruns = DagRun.find(
                dag_id=dag.dag_id,
                state=State.RUNNING,
                external_trigger=False,
                session=session
            )
```

@bolkedebruin @mistercrunch @plypaul ?

task_instances are created with execution_date being part of the primary key. As we still are a bit inconsistent with the dag_runs, there is no real primary key connection. However the most consistent way of doing a lookup of the dag_run is by dag_id and execution_date. Therefore the change looks good.

I do indeed wonder why we havent seen any side effects of using start_date until now, but that might have been because we are not using a task start_date as much (none actually). We should consider removing the functionality to set start_dates on tasks. It does not seem to make sense.

+1
Any feedback @alexvanboxel ? I would like to merge this, although it might not solve your issue.
Only ran it local, not yet on staging. But visually it looks good. I'll be backing a new version based on master (so if you merged it it will get tested next week).
Maybe add a comment of the extra dependency that needs to be included.
Please can you squash the PR to 1 commit

@plypaul any updates here? Can you have someone review and merge this at the earliest? Else, I will need to close this for inactivity.

Some more analysis. Testing with the following DAG: Which has the code below: ``` from airflow import DAG from airflow.operators.dummy_operator import DummyOperator from datetime import datetime, timedelta now = datetime.now() now_to_the_hour = (now - timedelta(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 3)).replace(minute=0, second=0, microsecond=0) START_DATE = now_to_the_hour DAG_NAME = 'test_dag_v1' default_args = { 'owner': 'airflow', 'depends_on_past': True, 'start_date': START_DATE, } dag = DAG(DAG_NAME, schedule_interval='*/10 * * * *', default_args=default_args) run_this_1 = DummyOperator(task_id='run_this_1', dag=dag) run_this_2 = DummyOperator(task_id='run_this_2', dag=dag) run_this_2.set_upstream(run_this_1) run_this_3 = DummyOperator(task_id='run_this_3', dag=dag) run_this_3.set_upstream(run_this_2) ``` Looking in the task_instance and dag_run tables, I see: ``` airflow=# select dag_id, execution_date, start_date from dag_run where dag_id='test_dag_v1' order by execution_date, start_date; dag_id | execution_date | start_date -------------+---------------------+---------------------------- test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:00:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:50.783843 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:10:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:54.007912 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:20:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:55.893759 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:30:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:57.9688 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:40:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:00.019746 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:50:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:02.144907 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:00:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:04.583202 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:10:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:06.25146 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:20:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:08.284404 (9 rows) airflow=# select dag_id, execution_date, start_date from task_instance where dag_id='test_dag_v1' order by execution_date, start_date; dag_id | execution_date | start_date -------------+---------------------+---------------------------- test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:00:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:54.764674 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:00:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:58.464516 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:00:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:02.740646 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:10:00 | 2016-10-28 15:04:58.465502 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:10:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:02.744096 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:10:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:06.920382 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:20:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:02.741751 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:20:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:06.920264 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:20:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:10.902551 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:30:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:06.920218 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:30:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:10.899725 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:30:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:40:00 | 2016-10-28 15:05:10.898504 test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:40:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:40:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:50:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:50:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 12:50:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:00:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:00:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:00:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:10:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:10:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:10:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:20:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:20:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:20:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:30:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:30:00 | test_dag_v1 | 2016-10-28 13:30:00 | (30 rows) ``` The start_dates for dag_run and for task_instance will never match except through coincidence. Placing some print statements near where these are checked, it seems to bear witness. +1

@btallman Let me know the status of this PR. It's drifted into the Cold Case PR zone and I would like to resolve it one way or another. Adding this PR to those I am tracking personally for Cold Case Clean Up.

BTW, as part of testing release candidates for 1.8, we will need to run setup.py. I have had to stop using setup.py because it's non-deterministic and has created a ton of problems for us - so much so that we are just pip installing releases now in prod and staging envs. 

Before we can test 1.8 rc.x, we will need this PR to get across the line.

So we use this all the time. We leverage the Variables as config, and so
getting sane defaults into the DB is very helpful for us and makes
migration from Dev->Qa->Prod much more stable.

There were a few comments about how this is a bad idea, and a get should
never set a value, but as we already support defaults, giving a way to put
those in the DB makes our system more stable. Basically, you get to see
what the default is, and edit it, instead of trying to remember them.

We currently handle this in our helper object, but it is MUCH cleaner to
add them. Basically, it adds an extra parameter to the Variable.Get and if
there is a default AND the extra param is set, the default is written to
the DB if the value doesn't exist. This allows us to see, when looking at
the Variable screen, what the supported variables are.

Just makes things more readable in a real world ops environment.

Thanks,
Ben

I fixed the obvious docstrings. I looked into the whitespaces around - (pep8), but when these are parameters it's supposed to be like this. I ran flake8 and it started complaining when I inserted the spaces.

Personally, I like the functionality and see it as valuable; I just question the semantics. The builtin `dict` type has both `get` and `setdefault` methods; the former gets a value or returns a default if the key is not present (without altering the dict) and the latter does the same but alters the dict to contain the default value.

Making a new, `setdefault` method on `Variable` parallels the semantics for the python standard library (thus sticking to the least surprise principle):

https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict.get
https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict.setdefault

Interesting. I'd never seen setdefault, as it isn't an obvious name for
get...  :)

Thanks,
Ben

I can't say for certain but I don't think that the test failures are your fault. You might be able to squash and rebase, to see if that fixes things (or gets more tests to pass).

From http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28509481/should-i-pin-my-python-dependencies-versions

> You should always pin your dependencies as it increases the possibility of safe, repeatable builds, even as time passes. The pinned versions are your declaration as a package maintainer that you've verified that your code works in a given environment. This has a nice side effect of preserving your sanity as you won't be inundated with bug reports in which you have to play inspector into every package codependency and system detail.
> Users can always choose to ignore the pinned dependency-versions and do so at their own risk. However, as you release new versions of your library, you should update your dependency versions to take in improvements and bug fixes.

I tend to agree but have read other articles that claim the opposite. I'm not sure what to do here. Python doesn't do nice with diamond dependencies with 2 different versions. I wish python did like npm does on that regard: building a tree where different libs can each use different versions of the same lib.
